etymologies: mid 17th century; earliest use found in Edward Waterhouse. From post-classical Latin imperation-, imperatio order, command, arithmetical rule from classical Latin imperāt-, past participial stem of imperāre + -io

definitions: The action or fact of governing, commanding, or directing something; command; governance. Chiefly Philosophy and , with reference to an imperate action. Now somewhat rare.
In Jeremy Bentham's terminology: the exercising of command by a sovereign or other authority, as effected by ensuring obedience through the fear of punishment. Chiefly in "the power of imperation".

notes.text: Contrasted with contrectation, or the regulation and implementation of the punishment.
